{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-162-23-A |Item_parent=Sexually transmitted infections (STI): gonococcal, chlamydial, syphilis, human papillomavirus (HPV), trichomoniasis |Item_parent_short=Sexually transmitted infections (STI): gonococcal, chlamydial, syphilis, human papillomavirus (HPV), trichomoniasis |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the clinical signs of early syphilis |Description=None |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=23}} Early syphilis : - Primary: variable duration (usually 21 days) - Chancre: single ++, clean, indurated, genital background ++, spontaneous regression
o Caution: not all syphilitic chancres fully meet these criteria
§ Syphilis must be suspected until proven otherwise in the presence of any ulceration of the genitals. - Satellite ADP: non-inflammatory - Secondary: duration <1 year - Syphilitic roseola: pinkish macules on the trunk, no other functional symptoms - Papular syphilis: copper-coloured papules, variable number and location - General and extracutaneous signs: fever, headache, poly-ADP, etc. - Early latent: asymptomatic

question.title: What is a characteristic of early syphilis?
question.description: What is a key feature of early syphilis?

option_a.title: A single chancre that lasts for several months

option_b.title: A rash that appears on the palms of the hands

option_c.title: A general feeling of illness that can last for several years

option_d.title: A fever that can cause a headache and poly-ADP
